messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Elastic Graph Neural Networks

Paper Abstract: Abstract While many existing graph neural networks (GNNs) have been proven to perform ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-based graph smoothing that enforces smoothness globally, in this work we aim to further enhance the local smoothness adaptivity of GNNs via ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-based graph smoothing. As a result, we introduce a family of GNNs (Elastic GNNs) based on ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} and ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-based graph smoothing. In particular, we propose a novel and general message passing scheme into GNNs. This message passing algorithm is not only friendly to back-propagation training but also achieves the desired smoothing properties with a theoretical convergence guarantee. Experiments on semi-supervised learning tasks demonstrate that the proposed Elastic GNNs obtain better adaptivity on benchmark datasets and are significantly robust to graph adversarial attacks. The implementation of Elastic GNNs is available at https://github.com/lxiaorui/ElasticGNN.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The political blogosphere and the 2004 us election: divided they blog",
        "When labelled data hurts: Deep semi-supervised classification with the graph 1-laplacian",
        "Convex Analysis and Monotone Operator Theory in Hilbert Spaces",
        "An adaptive total variation algorithm for computing the balanced cut of a graph",
        "Multiclass total variation clustering",
        "Spectral clustering based on the graph p-laplacian",
        "A primal–dual fixed point algorithm for convex separable minimization with applications to image restoration",
        "Graph unrolling networks: Interpretable neural networks for graph signal denoising",
        "Spectral graph theory",
        "Convolutional neural networks on graphs with fast localized spectral filtering",
        "Sparse and redundant representations: from theory to applications in signal and image processing",
        "All you need is low (rank) defending against adversarial attacks on graphs",
        "Neural message passing for quantum chemistry",
        "Inductive representation learning on large graphs",
        "Statistical Learning with Sparsity: The Lasso and Generalizations",
        "Graph structure learning for robust graph neural networks",
        "Semi-supervised learning via sparse label propagation",
        "Semi-supervised learning in network-structured data via total variation minimization",
        "ℓ1subscriptℓ1\\ell_{1} trend filtering",
        "Adam: A method for stochastic optimization",
        "Semi-supervised classification with graph convolutional networks",
        "Predict then propagate: Graph neural networks meet personalized pagerank",
        "Deeprobust: A pytorch library for adversarial attacks and defenses",
        "A primal-dual algorithm with optimal stepsizes and its application in decentralized consensus optimization",
        "On a generalization of the iterative soft-thresholding algorithm for the case of non-separable penalty",
        "Deep Learning on Graphs",
        "A unified view on graph neural networks as graph signal denoising",
        "Unsupervised and semi-supervised learning via ℓ1subscriptℓ1\\ell_{1}-norm graph",
        "Revisiting graph neural networks: All we have is low-pass filters",
        "A unified framework for convolution-based graph neural networks",
        "Nonlinear total variation based noise removal algorithms",
        "The graph neural network model",
        "Collective classification in network data",
        "Sparsistency of the edge lasso over graphs",
        "Pitfalls of graph neural network evaluation",
        "Total variation, cheeger cuts",
        "Sparsity and smoothness via the fused lasso",
        "Adaptive piecewise polynomial estimation via trend filtering",
        "Vector-valued graph trend filtering with non-convex penalties",
        "Graph attention networks",
        "Trend filtering on graphs",
        "Simplifying graph convolutional networks",
        "Pairnorm: Tackling oversmoothing in gnns",
        "Learning with local and global consistency",
        "Interpreting and unifying graph neural networks with an optimization framework",
        "Learning from labeled and unlabeled data with label propagation",
        "Semi-supervised learning literature survey",
        "Adversarial attacks on graph neural networks via meta learning",
        "Adversarial attacks on neural networks for graph data"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Elastic Graph Neural Networks, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
